text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in Serbian and Montenegrin press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
-- S E R B I A --
POLITIKA
- This year's grain yield in Serbia twice last year's; 300,000 tonnes surplus for exports, says Serbian agriculture minister. Farmers will also be able to pay taxes with grain.
- French cigarette giants look for investment prospects in Yugoslav tobacco sector.
- Process of privatisation of banks in Yugoslavia flowing smoothly, in contrast to that of industry.
- From August 1, import taxes to be slashed for industrial raw materials and also reduced for many consumer products.
NASA BORBA

- Belgrade lawyer beaten by Radical Party leader Vojislav Seselj's bodyguard after heated TV debate. Strong reactions from opposition politicians, who called for persecuting Seselj and banning his party.
- Serbian opposition leaders Vuk Draskovic and Zoran Djindjic meet for the first time since their coalition fell apart.
- Serbian Parliament moves towards adopting new election law dividing Serbia into 29 electoral districts. Opposition parties considering boycott of elections under those conditions.
BORBA
- Serbian parliament passes laws on financing political parties and amendments to law on election of MPs.
- Yugoslav government introduces regular weekly news conferences on Fridays on its activities and decisions.
- Yugoslav-Macedonian commissions in Skopje expected to sign bilateral trade agreement.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI
- Serbia's power company's outstanding claims from consumers 1.8 billion dinars.
DNEVNI TELEGRAF
- Opposition leader Zoran Djindjic claims state security planned to assassinate him.
- Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic reportedly told house guests he would rather commit suicide than let himself be arrested on war crimes charges and taken to the Hague.
POLITIKA EKSPRES
- Heavy rains in July slow down wheat harvesting. So far between 40 and 50 percent harvested in Serbia, says Miroslav Malesevic of Novi Sad Crop and Vegetable Farming Institute.
- No threats in Yugoslavia of Danube flooding.
DANAS
- The capitals of Croatia and Serbia increasingly similar in crime, more violent confrontations between mafia mobs.
- Kosovo Republic is a compromise between a natural solution of Kosovo-Albania and imposed status of Kosovo-Serbia, says Democratic League of Kosova vice president Hidajet Hiseni.
-- MONTENEGRO --
POBJEDA
- Montenegrin government says Yugoslav Justice Minister Zoran Knezevic is abusing his post by working against Montenegro.
- Sea-land container line to establish regular service from port of Bar.
- The Niksic steel mill produced 56,510 tonnes of crude steel in first six months of 1997, and sold 64,200 tonnes, up to 12 per cent less than planned.
- Novak Kilibarda's faction of opposition People's Party officially recognized as legal successor of the party. -- Belgrade newsroom +381 11 311 4305
